currentDoc:
How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we shouldn't be worried about screen use, we should be grateful that we have it. he benefits of screen time are so great that it is hard to imagine how we would have survived the pandemic without them.

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we shouldn't be worried about screen use, we should be grateful that we have it. he benefits of screen time are so great that it is hard to imagine how we would have survived the pandemic without them.

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we shouldn't be worried about screen use, we should be grateful that we have it. he benefits of screen time are so great that it is hard to imagine how we would have survived the pandemic without them.
 For starters, when the pandemic began, people quickly found ways of working remotely with the use of technology. Screen time became work time and with that, lots of people that normally work in an office were able to earn a living from home.
creen time also helped us tstayconnect edwith friends and family.

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we shouldn't be worried about screen use, we should be grateful that we have it. he benefits of screen time are so great that it is hard to imagine how we would have survived the pandemic without them.
 For starters, when the pandemic began, people quickly found ways of working remotely with the use of technology. Screen time became work time and with that, lots of people that normally work in an office were able to earn a living from home.
creen time also helped us tstayconnect edwith friends and family.

 For starters, when the pandemic began, people quickly found ways of working remotely with the use of technology. Screen time became work time and with that, lots of people that normally work in an office were able to earn a living from home.
creen time also helped us tstayconnect edwith friends and family.
 I know I have older family members who are hard of hearing, and the ability to face time them meant they could still see my face, which helped them better understand me. I'm sure there are many others who benefited this way in keeping up with family members. Screen time also helped us stay informed.

In my opinion, we shouldn't be worried about screen use, we should be grateful that we have it. he benefits of screen time are so great that it is hard to imagine how we would have survived the pandemic without them.
 For starters, when the pandemic began, people quickly found ways of working remotely with the use of technology. Screen time became work time and with that, lots of people that normally work in an office were able to earn a living from home.
creen time also helped us tstayconnect edwith friends and family.
 I know I have older family members who are hard of hearing, and the ability to face time them meant they could still see my face, which helped them better understand me. I'm sure there are many others who benefited this way in keeping up with family members. Screen time also helped us stay informed.

In my opinion, we shouldn't be worried about screen use, we should be grateful that we have it. he benefits of screen time are so great that it is hard to imagine how we would have survived the pandemic without them.
 For starters, when the pandemic began, people quickly found ways of working remotely with the use of technology. Screen time became work time and with that, lots of people that normally work in an office were able to earn a living from home.
creen time also helped us tstayconnect edwith friends and family.
 I know I have older family members who are hard of hearing, and the ability to face time them meant they could still see my face, which helped them better understand me. I'm sure there are many others who benefited this way in keeping up with family members. Screen time also helped us stay informed.

In my opinion, we shouldn't be worried about screen use, we should be grateful that we have it. he benefits of screen time are so great that it is hard to imagine how we would have survived the pandemic without them.
 For starters, when the pandemic began, people quickly found ways of working remotely with the use of technology. Screen time became work time and with that, lots of people that normally work in an office were able to earn a living from home.
creen time also helped us tstayconnect edwith friends and family.
 I know I have older family members who are hard of hearing, and the ability to face time them meant they could still see my face, which helped them better understand me. I'm sure there are many others who benefited this way in keeping up with family members. Screen time also helped us stay informed.

In my opinion, we shouldn't be worried about screen use, we should be grateful that we have it. he benefits of screen time are so great that it is hard to imagine how we would have survived the pandemic without them.

creen time also helped us tstayconnect edwith friends and family.
 I know I have older family members who are hard of hearing, and the ability to face time them meant they could still see my face, which helped them better understand me. I'm sure there are many others who benefited this way in keeping up with family members. Screen time also helped us stay informed.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we shouldn't be worried about screen use, we should be grateful that we have it. he benefits of screen time are so great that it is hard to imagine how we would have survived the pandemic without them.
 For starters, when the pandemic began, people quickly found ways of working remotely with the use of technology. Screen time became work time and with that, lots of people that normally work in an office were able to earn a living from home.
creen time also helped us tstayconnect edwith friends and family.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we shouldn't be worried about screen use, we should be grateful that we have it. he benefits of screen time are so great that it is hard to imagine how we would have survived the pandemic without them.
 For starters, when the pandemic began, people quickly found ways of working remotely with the use of technology. Screen time became work time and with that, lots of people that normally work in an office were able to earn a living from home.
creen time also helped us tstayconnect edwith friends and family.

In my opinion, we shouldn't be worried about screen use, we should be grateful that we have it. he benefits of screen time are so great that it is hard to imagine how we would have survived the pandemic without them.
 For starters, when the pandemic began, people quickly found ways of working remotely with the use of technology. Screen time became work time and with that, lots of people that normally work in an office were able to earn a living from home.
creen time also helped us tstayconnect edwith friends and family.
 I know I have older family members who are hard of hearing, and the ability to face time them meant they could still see my face, which helped them better understand me. I'm sure there are many others who benefited this way in keeping up with family members. Screen time also helped us stay informed.

I'm sure there are many others who benefited this way in keeping up with family members. Screen time also helped us stay informed.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we shouldn't be worried about screen use, we should be grateful that we have it. he benefits of screen time are so great that it is hard to imagine how we would have survived the pandemic without them.
 For starters, when the pandemic began, people quickly found ways of working remotely with the use of technology. Screen time became work time and with that, lots of people that normally work in an office were able to earn a living from home.
creen time also helped us tstayconnect edwith friends and family.

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we shouldn't be worried about screen use, we should be grateful that we have it. he benefits of screen time are so great that it is hard to imagine how we would have survived the pandemic without them.
 For starters, when the pandemic began, people quickly found ways of working remotely with the use of technology. Screen time became work time and with that, lots of people that normally work in an office were able to earn a living from home.
creen time also helped us tstayconnect edwith friends and family.

 I know I have older family members who are hard of hearing, and the ability to face time them meant they could still see my face, which helped them better understand me. I'm sure there are many others who benefited this way in keeping up with family members. Screen time also helped us stay informed.
 With so much going on during Covid, and our social lives put on hold, the internet or even the local news became our lifelines. How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we shouldn't be worried about screen use, we should be grateful that we have it. he benefits of screen time are so great that it is hard to imagine how we would have survived the pandemic without them.
 For starters, when the pandemic began, people quickly found ways of working remotely with the use of technology. Screen time became work time and with that, lots of people that normally work in an office were able to earn a living from home.
creen time also helped us tstayconnect edwith friends and family.
 I know I have older family members who are hard of hearing, and the ability to face time them meant they could still see my face, which helped them better understand me. I'm sure there are many others who benefited this way in keeping up with family members. Screen time also helped us stay informed.
 With so much going on during Covid, and our social lives put on hold, the internet or even the local news became our lifelines. I used to keep up with news by talking to people everyday, but with the start of Covid I was suddenly without that and had to depend on screen time of any sort in order to keep up with the many developing events. Scre

 With so much going on during Covid, and our social lives put on hold, the internet or even the local news became our lifelines. I used to keep up with news by talking to people everyday, but with the start of Covid I was suddenly without that and had to depend on screen time of any sort in order to keep up with the many developing events. How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we shouldn't be worried about screen use, we should be grateful that we have it. he benefits of screen time are so great that it is hard to imagine how we would have survived the pandemic without them.

SOne of the most helpful benefits of screen use the

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we shouldn't be worried about screen use, we should be grateful that we have it. he benefits of screen time are so great that it is hard to imagine how we would have survived the pandemic without them.
 For starters, when the pandemic began, people quickly found ways of working remotely with the use of technology. Screen time became work time and with that, lots of people that normally work in an office were able to earn a living from home.
creen time also helped us tstayconnect edwith friends and family.
 I know I have older family members who are hard of hearing, and the ability to face time them meant they could still see my face, which helped them better understand me. I'm sure there are many others who benefited this way in keeping up with family members. Screen time also helped us stay informed.
 With so much going on during Covid, and our social lives put on hold, the internet or even the local news became our lifelines. I used to keep up with news by talking to people everyday, but with the start of Covid I was suddenly without that and had to depend on screen time of any sort in order to keep up with the many developing events. I used to keep up with news by talking to people everyday, but with the start of Covid I was suddenly without that and had to depend on screen time of any sort in order to keep up with the many developing events. SOne of the most helpful benefits of screen use the past year or so has been the

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we shouldn't be worried about screen use, we should be grateful that we have it. he benefits of screen time are so great that it is hard to imagine how we would have survived the pandemic without them.
 For starters, when the pandemic began, people quickly found ways of working remotely with the use of technology. Screen time became work time and with that, lots of people that normally work in an office were able to earn a living from home.
creen time also helped us tstayconnect edwith friends and family.
 I know I have older family members who are hard of hearing, and the ability to face time them meant they could still see my face, which helped them better understand me. I'm sure there are many others who benefited this way in keeping up with family members. Screen time also helped us stay informed.

 For starters, when the pandemic began, people quickly found ways of working remotely with the use of technology. Screen time became work time and with that, lots of people that normally work in an office were able to earn a living from home.
creen time also helped us tstayconnect edwith friends and family.
 I know I have older family members who are hard of hearing, and the ability to face time them meant they could still see my face, which helped them better understand me. I'm sure there are many others who benefited this way in keeping up with family members. Screen time also helped us stay informed.
 With so much going on during Covid, and our social lives put on hold, the internet or even the local news became our lifelines. I used to keep up with news by talking to people everyday, but with the start of Covid I was suddenly without that and had to depend on screen time of any sort in order to keep up with the many developing events. SOne of the most helpful benefits of screen use the past year or so has been the ability of students to use

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we shouldn't be worried about screen use, we should be grateful that we have it. he benefits of screen time are so great that it is hard to imagine how we would have survived the pandemic without them.
 For starters, when the pandemic began, people quickly found ways of working remotely with the use of technology. Screen time became work time and with that, lots of people that normally work in an office were able to earn a living from home.
creen time also helped us tstayconnect edwith friends and family.

 With so much going on during Covid, and our social lives put on hold, the internet or even the local news became our lifelines. I used to keep up with news by talking to people everyday, but with the start of Covid I was suddenly without that and had to depend on screen time of any sort in order to keep up with the many developing events. SOne of the most helpful benefits of screen use the past year or so has been the ability of students to use their screens to continue school. It hasn't been p

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we shouldn't be worried about screen use, we should be grateful that we have it. he benefits of screen time are so great that it is hard to imagine how we would have survived the pandemic without them.
 For starters, when the pandemic began, people quickly found ways of working remotely with the use of technology. Screen time became work time and with that, lots of people that normally work in an office were able to earn a living from home.
creen time also helped us tstayconnect edwith friends and family.

 For starters, when the pandemic began, people quickly found ways of working remotely with the use of technology. Screen time became work time and with that, lots of people that normally work in an office were able to earn a living from home.
creen time also helped us tstayconnect edwith friends and family.
 I know I have older family members who are hard of hearing, and the ability to face time them meant they could still see my face, which helped them better understand me. I'm sure there are many others who benefited this way in keeping up with family members. Screen time also helped us stay informed.
 With so much going on during Covid, and our social lives put on hold, the internet or even the local news became our lifelines. I used to keep up with news by talking to people everyday, but with the start of Covid I was suddenly without that and had to depend on screen time of any sort in order to keep up with the many developing events. SOne of the most helpful benefits of screen use the past year or so has been the ability of students to use their screens to continue school. It hasn't been perfect but at least on som

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

I used to keep up with news by talking to people everyday, but with the start of Covid I was suddenly without that and had to depend on screen time of any sort in order to keep up with the many developing events. SOne of the most helpful benefits of screen use the past year or so has been the ability of students to use their screens to continue school. It hasn't been perfect but at least on some level, students have b

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we shouldn't be worried about screen use, we should be grateful that we have it. he benefits of screen time are so great that it is hard to imagine how we would have survived the pandemic without them.
 For starters, when the pandemic began, people quickly found ways of working remotely with the use of technology. Screen time became work time and with that, lots of people that normally work in an office were able to earn a living from home.
creen time also helped us tstayconnect edwith friends and family.
 I know I have older family members who are hard of hearing, and the ability to face time them meant they could still see my face, which helped them better understand me. SOne of the most helpful benefits of screen use the past year or so has been the ability of students to use their screens to continue school. It hasn't been perfect but at least on some level, students have been able to continue int

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we shouldn't be worried about screen use, we should be grateful that we have it. he benefits of screen time are so great that it is hard to imagine how we would have survived the pandemic without them.
 For starters, when the pandemic began, people quickly found ways of working remotely with the use of technology. Screen time became work time and with that, lots of people that normally work in an office were able to earn a living from home.
creen time also helped us tstayconnect edwith friends and family.
 I know I have older family members who are hard of hearing, and the ability to face time them meant they could still see my face, which helped them better understand me. I'm sure there are many others who benefited this way in keeping up with family members. Screen time also helped us stay informed.

I used to keep up with news by talking to people everyday, but with the start of Covid I was suddenly without that and had to depend on screen time of any sort in order to keep up with the many developing events. SOne of the most helpful benefits of screen use the past year or so has been the ability of students to use their screens to continue school. It hasn't been perfect but at least on some level, students have been able to continue interacting with educ

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we shouldn't be worried about screen use, we should be grateful that we have it. he benefits of screen time are so great that it is hard to imagine how we would have survived the pandemic without them.
 For starters, when the pandemic began, people quickly found ways of working remotely with the use of technology. Screen time became work time and with that, lots of people that normally work in an office were able to earn a living from home.
creen time also helped us tstayconnect edwith friends and family.
 I know I have older family members who are hard of hearing, and the ability to face time them meant they could still see my face, which helped them better understand me.  I know I have older family members who are hard of hearing, and the ability to face time them meant they could still see my face, which helped them better understand me. I'm sure there are many others who benefited this way in keeping up with family members. Screen time also helped us stay informed.
 With so much going on during Covid, and our social lives put on hold, the internet or even the local news became our lifelines. I used to keep up with news by talking to people everyday, but with the start of Covid I was suddenly without that and had to depend on screen time of any sort in order to keep up with the many developing events. How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we shouldn't be worried about screen use, we should be grateful that we have it. he benefits of screen time are so great that it is hard to imagine how we would have survived the pandemic without them.
 For starters, when the pandemic began, people quickly found ways of working remotely with the use of technology. Screen time became work time and with that, lots of people that normally work in an office were able to earn a living from home.
creen time also helped us tstayconnect edwith friends and family.
 I know I have older family members who are hard of hearing, and the ability to face time them meant they could still see my face, which helped them better understand me. I'm sure there are many others who benefited this way in keeping up with family members. Screen time also helped us stay informed.
 With so much going on during Covid, and our social lives put on hold, the internet or even the local news became our lifelines. I used to keep up with news by talking to people everyday, but with the start of Covid I was suddenly without that and had to depend on screen time of any sort in order to keep up with the many developing events. SOne of the most helpful benefits of screen use the past year or so has been the ability of students to use their screens to continue school. It hasn't been perfect but at least on some level, students have been able to continue interacting with educators and keeping some sort of pace as it pertai

 For starters, when the pandemic began, people quickly found ways of working remotely with the use of technology. Screen time became work time and with that, lots of people that normally work in an office were able to earn a living from home.
creen time also helped us tstayconnect edwith friends and family.
 I know I have older family members who are hard of hearing, and the ability to face time them meant they could still see my face, which helped them better understand me. I'm sure there are many others who benefited this way in keeping up with family members. Screen time also helped us stay informed.
 With so much going on during Covid, and our social lives put on hold, the internet or even the local news became our lifelines. I used to keep up with news by talking to people everyday, but with the start of Covid I was suddenly without that and had to depend on screen time of any sort in order to keep up with the many developing events. SOne of the most helpful benefits of screen use the past year or so has been the ability of students to use their screens to continue school. It hasn't been perfect but at least on some level, students have been able to continue interacting with educators and keeping some sort of pace as it pertains to learning.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

 For starters, when the pandemic began, people quickly found ways of working remotely with the use of technology. Screen time became work time and with that, lots of people that normally work in an office were able to earn a living from home.
creen time also helped us tstayconnect edwith friends and family.
 I know I have older family members who are hard of hearing, and the ability to face time them meant they could still see my face, which helped them better understand me. I'm sure there are many others who benefited this way in keeping up with family members. Screen time also helped us stay informed.
 With so much going on during Covid, and our social lives put on hold, the internet or even the local news became our lifelines. I used to keep up with news by talking to people everyday, but with the start of Covid I was suddenly without that and had to depend on screen time of any sort in order to keep up with the many developing events. SOne of the most helpful benefits of screen use the past year or so has been the ability of students to use their screens to continue school. It hasn't been perfect but at least on some level, students have been able to continue interacting with educators and keeping some sort of pace as it pertains to learning.

In my opinion, we shouldn't be worried about screen use, we should be grateful that we have it. he benefits of screen time are so great that it is hard to imagine how we would have survived the pandemic without them.
 For starters, when the pandemic began, people quickly found ways of working remotely with the use of technology. Screen time became work time and with that, lots of people that normally work in an office were able to earn a living from home.
creen time also helped us tstayconnect edwith friends and family.
 I know I have older family members who are hard of hearing, and the ability to face time them meant they could still see my face, which helped them better understand me. I'm sure there are many others who benefited this way in keeping up with family members. Screen time also helped us stay informed.
 With so much going on during Covid, and our social lives put on hold, the internet or even the local news became our lifelines. I used to keep up with news by talking to people everyday, but with the start of Covid I was suddenly without that and had to depend on screen time of any sort in order to keep up with the many developing events. SOne of the most helpful benefits of screen use the past year or so has been the ability of students to use their screens to continue school. It hasn't been perfect but at least on some level, students have been able to continue interacting with educators and keeping some sort of pace as it pertains to learning. 
I know excessive screen use has its pote

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we shouldn't be worried about screen use, we should be grateful that we have it. he benefits of screen time are so great that it is hard to imagine how we would have survived the pandemic without them.
 For starters, when the pandemic began, people quickly found ways of working remotely with the use of technology. Screen time became work time and with that, lots of people that normally work in an office were able to earn a living from home.
creen time also helped us tstayconnect edwith friends and family.
 I know I have older family members who are hard of hearing, and the ability to face time them meant they could still see my face, which helped them better understand me. I'm sure there are many others who benefited this way in keeping up with family members. Screen time also helped us stay informed.
 With so much going on during Covid, and our social lives put on hold, the internet or even the local news became our lifelines. I used to keep up with news by talking to people everyday, but with the start of Covid I was suddenly without that and had to depend on screen time of any sort in order to keep up with the many developing events. SOne of the most helpful benefits of screen use the past year or so has been the ability of students to use their screens to continue school. It hasn't been perfect but at least on some level, students have been able to continue interacting with educators and keeping some sort of pace as it pertains to learning. 
I know excessive screen use has its potential downsides, but i

I used to keep up with news by talking to people everyday, but with the start of Covid I was suddenly without that and had to depend on screen time of any sort in order to keep up with the many developing events. SOne of the most helpful benefits of screen use the past year or so has been the ability of students to use their screens to continue school. It hasn't been perfect but at least on some level, students have been able to continue interacting with educators and keeping some sort of pace as it pertains to learning. 
I know excessive screen use has its potential downsides, but in today's situati

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we shouldn't be worried about screen use, we should be grateful that we have it. he benefits of screen time are so great that it is hard to imagine how we would have survived the pandemic without them.
 For starters, when the pandemic began, people quickly found ways of working remotely with the use of technology. Screen time became work time and with that, lots of people that normally work in an office were able to earn a living from home.
creen time also helped us tstayconnect edwith friends and family.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we shouldn't be worried about screen use, we should be grateful that we have it. he benefits of screen time are so great that it is hard to imagine how we would have survived the pandemic without them.
 For starters, when the pandemic began, people quickly found ways of working remotely with the use of technology. Screen time became work time and with that, lots of people that normally work in an office were able to earn a living from home.
creen time also helped us tstayconnect edwith friends and family.
 I know I have older family members who are hard of hearing, and the ability to face time them meant they could still see my face, which helped them better understand me. I'm sure there are many others who benefited this way in keeping up with family members. Screen time also helped us stay informed.
 With so much going on during Covid, and our social lives put on hold, the internet or even the local news became our lifelines. I used to keep up with news by talking to people everyday, but with the start of Covid I was suddenly without that and had to depend on screen time of any sort in order to keep up with the many developing events. SOne of the most helpful benefits of screen use the past year or so has been the ability of students to use their screens to continue school. It hasn't been perfect but at least on some level, students have been able to continue interacting with educators and keeping some sort of pace as it pertains to learning. 
I know excessive screen use has its potential downsides, but in today's situation it should not be of co

 For starters, when the pandemic began, people quickly found ways of working remotely with the use of technology. Screen time became work time and with that, lots of people that normally work in an office were able to earn a living from home.
creen time also helped us tstayconnect edwith friends and family.
 I know I have older family members who are hard of hearing, and the ability to face time them meant they could still see my face, which helped them better understand me. I'm sure there are many others who benefited this way in keeping up with family members. Screen time also helped us stay informed.
 With so much going on during Covid, and our social lives put on hold, the internet or even the local news became our lifelines. I used to keep up with news by talking to people everyday, but with the start of Covid I was suddenly without that and had to depend on screen time of any sort in order to keep up with the many developing events. SOne of the most helpful benefits of screen use the past year or so has been the ability of students to use their screens to continue school. It hasn't been perfect but at least on some level, students have been able to continue interacting with educators and keeping some sort of pace as it pertains to learning. 
I know excessive screen use has its potential downsides, but in today's situation it should not be of concern. There are far m

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

 For starters, when the pandemic began, people quickly found ways of working remotely with the use of technology. Screen time became work time and with that, lots of people that normally work in an office were able to earn a living from home.
creen time also helped us tstayconnect edwith friends and family.
 I know I have older family members who are hard of hearing, and the ability to face time them meant they could still see my face, which helped them better understand me. I'm sure there are many others who benefited this way in keeping up with family members. Screen time also helped us stay informed.
 With so much going on during Covid, and our social lives put on hold, the internet or even the local news became our lifelines. I used to keep up with news by talking to people everyday, but with the start of Covid I was suddenly without that and had to depend on screen time of any sort in order to keep up with the many developing events. SOne of the most helpful benefits of screen use the past year or so has been the ability of students to use their screens to continue school. It hasn't been perfect but at least on some level, students have been able to continue interacting with educators and keeping some sort of pace as it pertains to learning. 
I know excessive screen use has its potential downsides, but in today's situation it should not be of concern. There are far more benefits of our s

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

In my opinion, we shouldn't be worried about screen use, we should be grateful that we have it. he benefits of screen time are so great that it is hard to imagine how we would have survived the pandemic without them.
 For starters, when the pandemic began, people quickly found ways of working remotely with the use of technology. Screen time became work time and with that, lots of people that normally work in an office were able to earn a living from home.
creen time also helped us tstayconnect edwith friends and family.
 I know I have older family members who are hard of hearing, and the ability to face time them meant they could still see my face, which helped them better understand me. I'm sure there are many others who benefited this way in keeping up with family members. Screen time also helped us stay informed.
 With so much going on during Covid, and our social lives put on hold, the internet or even the local news became our lifelines. I used to keep up with news by talking to people everyday, but with the start of Covid I was suddenly without that and had to depend on screen time of any sort in order to keep up with the many developing events. SOne of the most helpful benefits of screen use the past year or so has been the ability of students to use their screens to continue school. It hasn't been perfect but at least on some level, students have been able to continue interacting with educators and keeping some sort of pace as it pertains to learning. 
I know excessive screen use has its potential downsides, but in today's situation it should not be of concern. There are far more benefits of our screen use in this mome

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we shouldn't be worried about screen use, we should be grateful that we have it. he benefits of screen time are so great that it is hard to imagine how we would have survived the pandemic without them.
 For starters, when the pandemic began, people quickly found ways of working remotely with the use of technology. Screen time became work time and with that, lots of people that normally work in an office were able to earn a living from home.
creen time also helped us tstayconnect edwith friends and family.
 I know I have older family members who are hard of hearing, and the ability to face time them meant they could still see my face, which helped them better understand me. I'm sure there are many others who benefited this way in keeping up with family members. Screen time also helped us stay informed.
 With so much going on during Covid, and our social lives put on hold, the internet or even the local news became our lifelines. I used to keep up with news by talking to people everyday, but with the start of Covid I was suddenly without that and had to depend on screen time of any sort in order to keep up with the many developing events. SOne of the most helpful benefits of screen use the past year or so has been the ability of students to use their screens to continue school. It hasn't been perfect but at least on some level, students have been able to continue interacting with educators and keeping some sort of pace as it pertains to learning. 
I know excessive screen use has its potential downsides, but in today's situation it should not be of concern. There are far more benefits of our screen use in this moment than problems t

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we shouldn't be worried about screen use, we should be grateful that we have it. he benefits of screen time are so great that it is hard to imagine how we would have survived the pandemic without them.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we shouldn't be worried about screen use, we should be grateful that we have it. he benefits of screen time are so great that it is hard to imagine how we would have survived the pandemic without them.
 For starters, when the pandemic began, people quickly found ways of working remotely with the use of technology. Screen time became work time and with that, lots of people that normally work in an office were able to earn a living from home.
creen time also helped us tstayconnect edwith friends and family.
 I know I have older family members who are hard of hearing, and the ability to face time them meant they could still see my face, which helped them better understand me. I'm sure there are many others who benefited this way in keeping up with family members. Screen time also helped us stay informed.
 With so much going on during Covid, and our social lives put on hold, the internet or even the local news became our lifelines. I used to keep up with news by talking to people everyday, but with the start of Covid I was suddenly without that and had to depend on screen time of any sort in order to keep up with the many developing events. SOne of the most helpful benefits of screen use the past year or so has been the ability of students to use their screens to continue school. It hasn't been perfect but at least on some level, students have been able to continue interacting with educators and keeping some sort of pace as it pertains to learning. 
I know excessive screen use has its potential downsides, but in today's situation it should not be of concern. There are far more benefits of our screen use in this moment than problems to worry about.  In conclusion, no

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we shouldn't be worried about screen use, we should be grateful that we have it. he benefits of screen time are so great that it is hard to imagine how we would have survived the pandemic without them.
 For starters, when the pandemic began, people quickly found ways of working remotely with the use of technology. Screen time became work time and with that, lots of people that normally work in an office were able to earn a living from home.
creen time also helped us tstayconnect edwith friends and family.
 I know I have older family members who are hard of hearing, and the ability to face time them meant they could still see my face, which helped them better understand me. I'm sure there are many others who benefited this way in keeping up with family members. Screen time also helped us stay informed.
 With so much going on during Covid, and our social lives put on hold, the internet or even the local news became our lifelines. I used to keep up with news by talking to people everyday, but with the start of Covid I was suddenly without that and had to depend on screen time of any sort in order to keep up with the many developing events. SOne of the most helpful benefits of screen use the past year or so has been the ability of students to use their screens to continue school. It hasn't been perfect but at least on some level, students have been able to continue interacting with educators and keeping some sort of pace as it pertains to learning. 
I know excessive screen use has its potential downsides, but in today's situation it should not be of concern. There are far more benefits of our screen use in this moment than problems to worry about.  In conclusion, no, I do not think peopl

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we shouldn't be worried about screen use, we should be grateful that we have it. he benefits of screen time are so great that it is hard to imagine how we would have survived the pandemic without them.
 For starters, when the pandemic began, people quickly found ways of working remotely with the use of technology. Screen time became work time and with that, lots of people that normally work in an office were able to earn a living from home.
creen time also helped us tstayconnect edwith friends and family.
 I know I have older family members who are hard of hearing, and the ability to face time them meant they could still see my face, which helped them better understand me. I'm sure there are many others who benefited this way in keeping up with family members. Screen time also helped us stay informed.
 With so much going on during Covid, and our social lives put on hold, the internet or even the local news became our lifelines. I used to keep up with news by talking to people everyday, but with the start of Covid I was suddenly without that and had to depend on screen time of any sort in order to keep up with the many developing events. SOne of the most helpful benefits of screen use the past year or so has been the ability of students to use their screens to continue school. It hasn't been perfect but at least on some level, students have been able to continue interacting with educators and keeping some sort of pace as it pertains to learning. 
I know excessive screen use has its potential downsides, but in today's situation it should not be of concern. There are far more benefits of our screen use in this moment than problems to worry about.  In conclusion, no, I do not think people should be worried a

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we shouldn't be worried about screen use, we should be grateful that we have it. he benefits of screen time are so great that it is hard to imagine how we would have survived the pandemic without them.
 For starters, when the pandemic began, people quickly found ways of working remotely with the use of technology. Screen time became work time and with that, lots of people that normally work in an office were able to earn a living from home.
creen time also helped us tstayconnect edwith friends and family.
 I know I have older family members who are hard of hearing, and the ability to face time them meant they could still see my face, which helped them better understand me. I'm sure there are many others who benefited this way in keeping up with family members. Screen time also helped us stay informed.
 With so much going on during Covid, and our social lives put on hold, the internet or even the local news became our lifelines. I used to keep up with news by talking to people everyday, but with the start of Covid I was suddenly without that and had to depend on screen time of any sort in order to keep up with the many developing events. SOne of the most helpful benefits of screen use the past year or so has been the ability of students to use their screens to continue school. It hasn't been perfect but at least on some level, students have been able to continue interacting with educators and keeping some sort of pace as it pertains to learning. 
I know excessive screen use has its potential downsides, but in today's situation it should not be of concern. There are far more benefits of our screen use in this moment than problems to worry about.  In conclusion, no, I do not think people should be worried about excessive

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we shouldn't be worried about screen use, we should be grateful that we have it. he benefits of screen time are so great that it is hard to imagine how we would have survived the pandemic without them.
 For starters, when the pandemic began, people quickly found ways of working remotely with the use of technology. Screen time became work time and with that, lots of people that normally work in an office were able to earn a living from home.
creen time also helped us tstayconnect edwith friends and family.
 I know I have older family members who are hard of hearing, and the ability to face time them meant they could still see my face, which helped them better understand me. I'm sure there are many others who benefited this way in keeping up with family members. Screen time also helped us stay informed.
 With so much going on during Covid, and our social lives put on hold, the internet or even the local news became our lifelines. I used to keep up with news by talking to people everyday, but with the start of Covid I was suddenly without that and had to depend on screen time of any sort in order to keep up with the many developing events. SOne of the most helpful benefits of screen use the past year or so has been the ability of students to use their screens to continue school. It hasn't been perfect but at least on some level, students have been able to continue interacting with educators and keeping some sort of pace as it pertains to learning. 
I know excessive screen use has its potential downsides, but in today's situation it should not be of concern. There are far more benefits of our screen use in this moment than problems to worry about.  In conclusion, no, I do not think people should be worried about excessive screen use-At al
